title: udayantha11
author: udayantha11
content: I have a question thatIf i create a paper wallet , i got a public key and private key. so From using  public key we can send BTC from binance. whenever i need to send BTC to binance from  paper wallet , How can i do?i am confused

comments.author: TryNinja
comments.created_time: December 01, 2022, 05:17:22 AMLast edit: December 10, 2022, 02:15:45 PM by TryNinja
comments.body: Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:13:09 AMwhenever i need to send BTC to binance from  paper wallet , How can i do?That's what your private key is for. You could, for example, just download Electrum[1] (bitcoin wallet), import the private-key[2] and send the coins to whoever you want.Just make sure no one gets hold of your private key. Don't send them to anyone, be careful with fake popups and ads, don't download random software, etc...[1] https://electrum.org[2] https://bitcoinelectrum.com/importing-your-private-keys-into-electrum

comments.author: TryNinja
comments.body: Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:21:15 AMAre there any big fees for it? Just the transaction fee which is required for every transaction. Since the Bitcoin network usage is quite low right now, you should only spend a few cents. My last transfer costed me less than 10c.Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:21:15 AMi have downloaded exodus wallet , but there are asking 12pharse words. but we only have private key. so what is that differnace?Every Bitcoin address has a private key. If you have the private key, you can spend the coins of that address.Some wallets manage multiple addresses (usually a new address is generated for every transaction you receive, for privacy reasons), so they give you what they call a "backup seed", a list of words which represents what takes to generate the same addresses. It's used for backing up your wallet.Seed -> multiple private keys -> each private key -> each address

comments.body: Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:13:09 AMIf i create a paper wallet , i got a public key and private key. so From using  public key we can send BTC from binance. whenever i need to send BTC to binance from  paper walletOn Binance, you don't own private key of your Bitcoin. They are a centralized exchange with custodial wallet provided to users.I guess you want to send your BTC from your wallet to your Binance account, send BTC to Binance ?You can import your private key to Electrum and send your BTC to your Binance account. Open your Binance account, choose Deposit and get your Deposit address on Binance with BTC network. Remember to choose BTC network or BTC (Segwit) because you will make a transaction on Bitcoin network.In addition, when you make a transaction from your wallet, you use its private key to sign that transaction, not public key.

comments.body: Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:13:09 AMI have a question thatIf i create a paper wallet , i got a public key and private key. so From using  public key we can send BTC from binance. whenever i need to send BTC to binance from  paper wallet , How can i do?i am confusedYou can send btc from a cold storage to binance/any other btc wallet without worrying too much about having your private keys exposed online with the help of your master pub key.You just have to sign the transaction with an offline wallet then broadcast it online.More detailed guide: https://electrum.readthedocs.io/en/latest/coldstorage.htmlQuote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:49:33 AMIf electrum wallet hacked ,Electrum is an open-sourced wallet. comments.author: hosemary
comments.body: As already suggested in the previous posts, for spending fund from your paper wallet, you can import your private key into electrum. But note that you would defeat the purpose of the paper wallet if you import your private key in a device that has been connected to the internet. The purpose of a cold storage is that your private key doesn't connect to the internet at all. Otherwise, your wallet is no longer a cold storage. By the way, why don't you create a HD wallet instead of creating a single private key and a single address?

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:49:33 AMAre there any alternative rather than Electrum wallet. Anything can happen in crypto. If electrum wallet hacked , then what else we can do?There are alternatives, but Electrum is probably the easiest. You're using cold storage to stay safe from hacks, so you should sign your transaction offline:Quote from: LoyceV on February 19, 2021, 05:35:55 PMQuote from: mojolama on February 19, 2021, 05:12:41 PMI was considering Electrum, only downside is that when creating a wallet, seed creation is exposedOnline:Install Electrum on your PC.Import your address to create a watch-only wallet.Preview the transaction, Copy the unsigned transaction. Put it on a USB stick.Offline and running without hard drive storage:Get a Linux LIVE DVD. Use Knoppix or Tails for instance, or any other distribution that comes with Electrum pre-installed.Unplug your internet cable. Close the curtains. Reboot your computer and start up from that DVD. Don't enter any wireless connection password. Keep it offline.Start Electrum. Import your private key.Copy your unsigned transaction from the USB stick, load it into Electrum.CHECK the transaction in Electrum. Check the fees, check the amount, check all destination addresses (character by character).If all is okay, sign the transaction. Copy it back to your USB stick.Turn off the computer. That wipes the Live LINUX from memory and all traces are gone.Online:Use your normal online Electrum to (check again and) broadcast the transaction.Bonus:After moving all your Bitcoin, and once the transaction confirmed, check if you own Forkcoins.Also: when sweeping paper wallets, you should move the entire balance at once. Or manually set a change address (which could be a new paper wallet).Warning: some of the paper wallet websites from back in the days now produce compromised paper wallets. Don't trust them anymore!

comments.body: Quote from: udayantha11 on December 01, 2022, 05:49:33 AMAre there any alternative rather than Electrum wallet.Any wallet which allows you to import raw private keys would suffice. Although I agree Electrum is the best and safest wallet for this task, my go-to secondary piece of light wallet software is Sparrow wallet, which would also be able to import from a paper wallet no problem.If you are going to use Electrum, note that you'll need to prefix your private key with p2wpkh: if your paper wallet has generated a segwit (bc1q) address.

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: Lida93 on December 14, 2022, 08:21:05 PMAs long as you have a good operating system you need not worryYou're missing the point of cold storage. You can't know for sure whether or not your OS is secure, so the only way to "not worry", is by keeping your keys offline instead of gambling nothing will go wrong. Even if it's only a 1% chance, that's a huge risk if you're handling your life savings.Also: fix your quotes!
